maybe



struct Maybe(T);
Contains either a value or nothing, guaranteeing the value is not accessible if invalid.

Note:
The abstraction can be circumvented using e.g. Maybe.valueOr(null), but at least this is explicit.

bool opEquals(T v);
Tests whether the Maybe value is valid and equal to v. 
 assert(maybe(5) == 5);
 assert(maybe(5) != 6);


bool opEquals(Maybe!(T) m);
Tests whether the Maybe value is valid, m is valid, and both values are equal. 
 assert(maybe(5) == maybe(5));
 assert(maybe(5) != maybe(6));


bool opEquals(typeof(null));
Tests whether the Maybe value is invalid. 
 assert(Maybe!int() == null);
 assert(maybe(5) != null);


bool attempt(scope void delegate(T) fun);
Calls fun if the Maybe value is valid.

Returns:
Whether fun was called or not.

Maybe!(U) map(U)(scope U delegate(T) fun);
Attempts to call fun, wrapping the result as a Maybe.

Maybe!(T) filter(scope bool delegate(T) pred);
Returns a copy of the Maybe struct if pred returns true, or an invalid Maybe struct if pred returns false.

T valueOr(T invalid_value);
Converts the Maybe value into a T, returning invalid_value if invalid. The argument can be null, but at least the user is reminded of it: 
 Maybe!Object m = ...;
 Object w = m.valueOr(alternativeObject);
 Object v = m.valueOr(null);


Params:
T invalid_value Value to return if the Maybe value is invalid.

Note:
It's safer to avoid using valueOr if possible.

auto match(alias validFun, alias invalidFun, Args...)(Args args);
Attempts to call validFun(args), but with any Maybe instances in args unwrapped. If any Maybe instance in args is invalid, calls invalidFun(). invalidFun may return either void or the same type as validFun.

Returns:
The result of validFun/invalidFun, if any, wrapped in a Maybe.

auto apply(alias fun, Args...)(Args args);
Attempts to call fun(args), but with any Maybe instances in args unwrapped. Does nothing if any Maybe instance in args is invalid.

Returns:
The result of fun, if any, wrapped in a Maybe.
